title: James, a college athlete's journey post-traumatic brain injury
clinical_history: James is a 21-year-old college football player who, six weeks ago, experienced a severe collision during a game. He was tackled head-on and lost consciousness temporarily on the field for around three minutes. He was immediately taken off the field and assessed by the medical team. Post-injury, he has been experiencing severe headaches, dizziness, and difficulty concentrating, especially when exposed to bright lights or loud environments. He also reports persistent feelings of fatigue, irritability, and changes in his sleep pattern, finding it hard to maintain a consistent sleep schedule.

nprs.affected_area: frontal and occipital regions of the head

aggrevating_factors: engaging in cognitive tasks like studying, exposure to screens for prolonged periods, physical exertion, loud noises, and bright lights
picture: [insert image of a human brain with areas affected by impact highlighted]
easing_factors: rest in a dark, quiet room, brief naps, light stretching
past_history: previous mild concussions during high school, but recovered fully each time with no enduring effects.
medical_history: no significant medical conditions aside from common colds and minor sports injuries
medications: acetaminophen for headaches, melatonin to aid sleep rhythm
personal_history: Currently pursuing a degree in sports science. Lives on campus with three other teammates. Has a supportive family; his parents live in another state. He is generally healthy, participates actively in sports, and has no known serious pre-existing conditions.
imaging: CT scan on the day of injury showed no structural damage. Follow-up MRI also revealed no significant abnormalities.
